articles.headline: U.S. Man Accused of Helping Plot Mumbai Attack
articles.snippet: Prosecutors said that David C. Headley, charged in a plot against a Danish newspaper, scouted targets in Mumbai.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors said that David C. Headley, charged in a plot against a Danish newspaper, scouted targets in Mumbai.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  An American at the center of an international terrorism investigation has been charged with helping plot the 2008 rampage in Mumbai, India, that left 163 people dead, according to a Justice Department complaint unsealed on Monday.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson and David Johnston

articles.headline: Dark Side of a Natural Gas Boom
articles.snippet: Some environmentalists are concerned that a technology called hydraulic fracturing used to produce natural gas could be leading to pollution.
articles.abstract: Some environmentalists are concerned that a technology called hydraulic fracturing used to produce natural gas could be leading to pollution.
articles.lead_paragraph: DIMOCK, Pa.  Victoria Switzer dreamed of a peaceful retirement in these Appalachian hills. Instead, she is coping with a big problem after a nearby natural gas well contaminated her family’s drinking water with high levels of methane.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Google Adds Live Updates to Results
articles.snippet: Google will supplement its search results with updates posted each second to sites like Twitter and Facebook.
articles.abstract: Google will supplement its search results with updates posted each second to sites like Twitter and Facebook.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Unveiling significant changes to its dominant search engine on Monday, Google said it would begin supplementing its search results with the updates posted each second to sites like Twitter, Facebook and MySpace.

articles.headline: Millions in U.S. Drink Dirty Water, Records Show
articles.snippet: More than 20 percent of water treatment systems have violated key provisions of the Safe Drinking Water Act.
articles.abstract: More than 20 percent of water treatment systems have violated key provisions of the Safe Drinking Water Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 20 percent of the nation’s water treatment systems have violated key provisions of the Safe Drinking Water Act over the last five years, according to a New York Times analysis of federal data.

articles.headline: Bailout Refund Is All About Pay, Pay, Pay
articles.snippet: With Bank of America trying to recruit a new chief executive, it needed to repay the bailout moneys so it would be able to offer a competitive compensation package.
articles.abstract: With Bank of America trying to recruit a new chief executive, it needed to repay the bailout moneys so it would be able to offer a competitive compensation package.

articles.headline: Debt Raters Avoid Overhaul After Crisis
articles.snippet: Experts say that Washington’s overhaul of the Big Three credit rating agencies is not going far enough.
articles.abstract: Experts say that Washington’s overhaul of the Big Three credit rating agencies is not going far enough.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the financial crisis began, few players on Wall Street looked more ripe for reform than the Big Three credit rating agencies.

articles.headline: Pakistan Told to Ratchet Up Taliban Fight
articles.snippet: The Obama administration warned that if Pakistan does not act aggressively, the U.S. will use more force on the Pakistani side of the border.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration warned that if Pakistan does not act aggressively, the U.S. will use more force on the Pakistani side of the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is turning up the pressure on Pakistan to fight the Taliban inside its borders, warning that if it does not act more aggressively the United States will use considerably more force on the Pakistani side of the border to shut down Taliban attacks on American forces in Afghanistan, American and Pakistani officials said.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Civil Suit Says Lender Ignored Own Warnings
articles.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission said New Century executives must have known from in-house reports that the company was hemorrhaging money.
articles.abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said New Century executives must have known from in-house reports that the company was hemorrhaging money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like clockwork, the bulletins arrived from California’s Mortgage Alley, each bearing the same ominous title: “Storm Watch.”

articles.headline: A Flush G.M. to Lavish Cash on New Vehicles
articles.snippet: During the automaker’s slide into bankruptcy, it had to suspend some of its investments. But the new chief seems eager to play aggressive offense.
articles.abstract: During the automaker’s slide into bankruptcy, it had to suspend some of its investments. But the new chief seems eager to play aggressive offense.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the new chief executive of General Motors, has one big advantage as he tries to turn around the automaker  a stockpile of cash to develop new cars and trucks.
